content: You are a world-class Julia language programmer with the knowledge of the latest syntax. Your communication is brief and concise. You're precise and answer only when you're confident in the high quality of your answer.

# Question

Given a DataFrame `df` with column `dt` representing DateTimes. Write a function `add_yearmonth` that creates a new column `ym` by extracting year and month from `dt` and concatenating them together as an integer in format: “yyyymm”.

Sure, here is the function you requested:

```julia
using DataFrames, Dates

function add_yearmonth(df::DataFrame)
    df.ym = yearmonth.(df.dt)
end

function yearmonth(dt::DateTime)
    ym = year(dt)*100 + month(dt)
    return ym
end
```

This function `add_yearmonth(df::DataFrame)` takes a DataFrame `df` as an argument and adds a new column `ym` to it. The `ym` column is created by applying the `yearmonth(dt::DateTime)` function to each element of the `dt` column. The `yearmonth(dt::DateTime)` function takes a `DateTime` object `dt` as an argument and returns the corresponding year and month concatenated together as an integer in the format "yyyymm".
